The domain of a function is the set of all possible input values for which the function is defined. Every input value in the domain has a corresponding output in the codomain via the function.
Sign or Signature of a Permutation

The sign or signature of a permutation $\pi \in \mathfrak{S}_{n}$, denoted as $\operatorname{sgn} \pi$, is defined by the product $\prod_{i<j} \frac{\pi(i)-\pi(j)}{i-j}$. The sign can only assume the values 1 and -1. If $\operatorname{sgn} \pi$ is positive, $\pi$ is called an even permutation, and an odd permutation otherwise.
Does the concept of a/an Domain need to be defined for a definition of a/an Sign or Signature of a Permutation to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The concept of a Domain is inherently linked to the definition of any function, including permutations. A permutation $\\$\pi \\in \\\mathfrak{S}_{n}\\$ is a bijective function from the set \\$\{1, 2, ..., n\}\\$ to itself. This set \\$\{1, 2, ..., n\}\\$ is the domain of the permutation. The definition of the sign or signature of a permutation involves evaluating the permutation at different points within its domain (i.e., \\$\pi(i)\\$ and \\$\pi(j)\\$ for \\$i<j\\$). Therefore, understanding and defining the domain is crucial for making sense of how the permutation operates and subsequently for defining its sign or signature. Without a clear definition of the domain, it would be ambiguous as to what the inputs (i.e., \\$i\\$ and \\$j\\$) and the outputs (i.e., \\$\pi(i)\\$ and \\$\pi(j)\\$) of the permutation are, making the calculation of the sign undefined.
